newsitem.title: UK: Rolls sees solution for Cathay engine problem.
newsitem.headline: Rolls sees solution for Cathay engine problem.

text.p: Aero-engines manufacturer Rolls-Royce Plc said on Thursday that it thinks it has found the solution to the gearbox problem on its Trent 700 turbofan which caused two recent mid-air shutdowns. The Trent 700's biggest customer Cathay Pacific Airways has said one of its Airbus A330-300 aircraft had to make a single-engine landing at Bangkok last week and another was made two weeks ago when a flight to the Philippines had to turn back to Hong Kong. "The investigation in still continuing on the gearboxes in question but we believe we have a design solution," a company spokesman, Gary Atkins, said. Cathay operates 11 A330-300s using Trent 700 engines, while its sister airline Hong Kong Dragon Airlines (Dragonair) uses four and Indonesian airline Garuda operates another five. "Those are the only three operators of Trent 700 engines," Atkins said. He also said the problem with gearbox bearings was peculiar to the Trent 700 and was not connected with a problem encountered last year with its bigger Trent 800 powerplant, which powers the Boeing 777 twinjet.

B-777 operator Thai Airways International sent two of its Trent 800 engines back to Rolls for investigation after finding evidence of metal debris during routine ground inspections. "There is absolutely no connection at all," Atkins said. He explained that the problems with the 800 related to the gearbox and driveshaft shroud tubes but modifications have since been made. -- London Newsroom +44 171 542 7717
